item.title: Report E-2025040006
item.description:
Report E-2025040006

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-20T00:57:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-30
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8500
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Clean Harbors personnel arrived onsite and observed an estimated two hundred seventy-five (275) gallons were released from a two hundred seventy-five (275) gallon IBC plastic tote. It affected 100’-by-20’ area of concrete and a 3’-by-3’ area of trailer floor. It was damaged in the mechanical shop then placed on the trailer. Clean Harbors advised the mechanical shop that it needed pressure washed and flushed down the oil water separator. Granular absorbents were deployed to the affected areas. Clean Harbors then transferred seventy-five (75) gallons of remaining product into a new IBC plastic tote. It was then determined there were two hundred (200) gallons released. The generated waste was four (4) 55-gallon metal drums containing impacted absorbents and one (1) 85-gallon metal drum containing absorbents and cut up tote. The generated waste was staged onsite and will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal. The ESTES terminal supervisor approved all work before Hepaco departed.

item.title: Report E-2025040002
item.description:
Report E-2025040002

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-20T00:57:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-28
  • City: SAN DIEGO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 28, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon pail of Ultrasil 110 was punctured and released approximately one-half (0.5) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to clean the trailer floor. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and the damaged pail was containerized in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.description:
Report X-2025031544

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-20T00:57:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-21
  • City: NEWARK
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 03/21/2025 at approximately 1200 hours, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 164671 at the ramp facility in Newark, reporting a chloroform spill. The shipment consisted of 8 glass bottles packaged in a fiberboard box, one of which broke during transit. The cause of the damage is unknown. The shipment did not appear to have sufficient cushioning or inner slots for proper packaging, in accordance with IATA Section 5. The package is being held, pending an investigation by the FAA.

item.title: Report X-2025031540
item.description:
Report X-2025031540

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-20T00:57:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-19
  • City: FORT WORTH
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 03/19/2025 at approximately 1300 hours, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 393838 at the ramp facility in Fort Worth, reporting a presumed gasoline spill. The shipment consisted of one fiberboard box that contained about 4 glass bottles of liquid. The shipment was discovered where liquid had completely absorbed into the outer packaging and emitted a gasoline odor. Further investigation revealed one broken bottle and a saturated safety data sheet "crude oil" inside of the box for; however, the odor from the shipment indicates otherwise. The shipment displayed an Excepted Quantities mark, but the amount of liquid in each inner contents appears to exceed the limits shown in IATA Regulations. The shipment is being held. pending an FAA investigation.

item.title: Report E-2025030196
item.description:
Report E-2025030196

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-20T00:57:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-12
  • City: JACKSONVILLE
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 1200
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 3/12/2025, at 12:29 hours, FRA Inspector David Robinson, reported at the CSX Moncrief Yard in Jacksonville, Florida the GATX 205634, a loaded tank car of Flammable Liquid, N.O.S (Turpentine) was leaking from the vapor line valve. The car was isolated and the shipper, International Paper Co, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2025031200135). Hulls Environmental, a CSXT response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the vapor line valve partially open and secondary closure plug less than tool tight. Contractor personnel closed the vapor line valve and properly tool tighten the secondary closure plug. Contractor personnel also corrected 1 of 6 manway swing bolts less than tool tight that was identified by the FRA inspector. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Marceia Cox (901-229-4591).

item.description:
Report X-2025031534

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-15T00:53:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-27
  • City: ONTARIO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: TWO PACKAGES FROM COLORADO TO ALASKA BECAME WET FROM RAINWATER IN ONTARIO, CALIFORNIA. DURING PACKAGE REWRAP WE FOUND TWO INNER BOXES IN EACH PACKAGE MARKED WITH UN3481 BATTERY MARKS. EACH OF THOSE INNER BOXES CONTAINED TWENTY-FOUR JBL GO4 BLUETOOTH SPEAKERS WITH RECHARGEABLE LITHIUM ION BATTERIES INSIDE THE DEVICES. ADDITIONAL TRACKING NUMBER TO THE SAME CONSIGNEE IN ALASKA IS 1Z4928XV0319397364. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOXES. THESE PACKAGES HAVE NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

item.title: Report E-2025030441
item.description:
Report E-2025030441

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-15T00:53:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-27
  • City: LOUISVILLE
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Hepaco personnel arrived onsite and observed an estimated 3 gallons of material spilled from one (1) 330-gallon plastic IBC tote. The material released impacted the trailer and the concrete dock floor. Before Hepaco arrived, absorbents were placed around the tote. After a safety briefing, Hepaco began the tote transfer. When the tote transfer was complete, the damaged tote and impacted absorbents were placed into two (2) 55-gallon metal drums. The generated waste was staged onsite and will remain onsite for the Dayton Freight team to coordinate disposal. The Dayton Freight POC approved all work before Hepaco departed.

  • Description: On March 27, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon pail of paint was punctured and released approximately five (5) gallons of paint to the trailer interior and pavement below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services, Inc. (HES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted areas. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and the damaged pail was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one hundred (100) pounds of material released from two (2) 50-pound plastic bags due to a puncture that resulted from a forklift accident. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight containerized the released material into two (2) 5-gallon poly drums. A third 5-gallon poly drum containerized the damaged plastic bags. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: ONE AIR PACKAGE WAS SUSPECTED TO CONTAIN UNDECLARED DANGEROUS GOODS DUE TO A SIMILAR PACKAGE BEING FOUND THE DAY PRIOR. CONTENT INSPECTION REVEALS TWO CANS OF TEN OUNCE CAPACITY FALCON DUST-OFF ELECTRONICS COMPRESSED AS DUSTER, DUST AND LINT REMOVER. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER PACKAGE. THE PACKAGE WAS DROPPED OFF IN TEXAS USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER 21X49A, HALLSTAR, 520 BROOME RD, GREENSBORO NC 27406. THIS ACCOUNT USAGE IS SUSPECTED TO BE UNAUTHORIZED. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-15T00:53:32+00:00

  • City: EARTH CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT APPROXIMATELY 20:45 AN UNLOAD SUPERVISOR CALLED DMP ABOUT A LEAKING PACKAGE IN DOOR 18 OF THE UNLOAD. A DESIGNATED RESPONDER DONNED PROPER PPE AND RETRIEVED A SPILL CART. ONCE ON THE SCENE OF THE SPILL THE RESPONDER NOTICED THE PACKAGE HAD BEEN CRUSHED AND LIQUID WAS LEAKING OUT OF THE CORNER. AFTER REFERRING TO THE DECISION TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET THE RESPONDER ACTED ACCORDINGLY. THE PACKAGE WAS TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP CAGE FOR FURTHER PROCESSING. AFTER OPENING THE PACKAGE IT WAS FOUND TO BE LEAKING DUE TO BEING CRUSHED AND THE CAP COMING LOOSE. THE PACKAGE WAS THEN DISPOSED OF ACCORDING TO THE DMP FLOW CHART.

THE PACKAGE WAS DROPPED OFF IN TEXAS USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER 220F94, RICHARD FARAGO, 19 KYLEMORE DR, WESTFORD MA 01886. THIS ACCOUNT USAGE IS SUSPECTED TO BE UNAUTHORIZED. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

item.description:
Report X-2025031433

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-15T00:53:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-24
  • City: ADDISON
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE HAZMAT AUDITOR FLOOR AREA, AUDITOR NOTICED LEAKING HAZMAT PACKAGE ON TOP OF ANOTHER HAMZAT PACKAGE. AUDITOR DIDN'T TOUCH THE LEAKING HAZMAT PACKAGE, LEFT THE AREA, AND NOTIFIED THEIR SUPERVISOR. SUPERVISOR NOTIFIED RMP AND RMP NOTIFIED DESIGNATED RESPONDER. RESPONDER ARRIVED WITH THEIR PPE ON, STOCKED SPILL CART, AND CURRENT DESICION TREE. RESPONDER NOTICED THAT THE LEAKING HAZMAT PACKAGE HAD A FLAMMABLE LIQUID LABEL. RESPONDER READ AND FOLLOWED CURRENT DESICION TREE, WHICH LED THEM TO THE FLAMMABLE LIQUID RESPONSE SHEET. SINCE THERE WAS ONLY CONTAMINATION ON ANOTHER HAZMAT PACKAGE AND NOT ELSEWHERE, ZEP ZORBENT WAS NOT NEEDED. RESPONDER CONTAINED LEAKING FLAMMABLE LIQUID HAZMAT PACKAGE AND GRABBED THE OTHER HAZMAT PACKAGE ONTO THE SPILL CART. RESPONDER HEADED BACK TO THE PSC CAGE WITH BOTH PACKAGES TO START PROCESSING. AFTER RESPONDER PROCESSED DAMAGED MATERIALS INTO A GREEN BAG, THEY DECONTAMINATED THEIR PPE.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Our driver was dropping NA1993 ULSD into our underground storage tank. The tank 90% flapper lid closed and stopped the flow of product. Our driver thought the rest of the product in the drop hose could fit, so the driver unlatched the drop fitting to let air in and the product to continue flowing into the tank. The flapper lid remained closed and the product spilled approximately 15 gallons onto our parking lot. Our driver used our trailer spill kit along with the store spill kit to contain the spill and clean up the area. No product reached any drains or soil. The product was disposed of into our hazardous waste bins.

item.title: Report E-2025030456
item.description:
Report E-2025030456

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-15T00:53:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-17
  • City: West Groton
  • State: MA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNIVAR SOLUTIONS USA INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Univar Solutions' driver was delivering Sulfuric acid to our customer in West Groton, MA. Customer advised driver on arrival that the load would not fit as it was ordered too early. Driver and customer planned to stop the delivery at 3600 gallons on customer's tank meter (relative to Storage tank capacity of 4000 gallons). During unload, driver went to check the meter at 3300 gallons and found the tank overflowing into the containment dike. The overflow was coming from the overflow pipe. It did not come out of the top of the tank at any time. Delivery was immediately stopped. Customer was notified of the spill as she was not aware it happened. Customer's Supervisor was alerted to the spill by the receiver. Customer supervisor advised their tank meter was inaccurate causing the overflow which was contained in the containment dike.

item.title: Report E-2025030452
item.description:
Report E-2025030452

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-15T00:53:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-16
  • City: EAU CLAIRE
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: SKYWEST AIRLINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: While the Aircraft loading agents were unloading the cargo bin of our CRJ 200, and as the checked bag was going down the belt loader, the bag caught fire. Seeing flames and smoke, the fire was reported to local emergency responders. The bag was extinguished using a fire extinguisher before the responders could arrive on scene. The crew and passengers were unaware if the incident occurred in flight or taxing to the gate. The duration of the event was only a few minutes until the items were extinguished. The aircraft cargo bin did not appear to have any damage and no smoke alarms inside the aircraft were reported. The aircraft was grounded until further inspections was made. Upon closer inspection of the bag, there was a small hole that had burned through the bag. Two of the personal electric battery powered items inside the bag were charred. An undetermined brand of cell phone and a Remington beard trimmer. It is undetermined which item caused this event. The national response center was notified shortly after the event.

  • Description: At 14:50 EST ERTS was contacted by XPO Logistics (LHO) about a cargo release. It was reported that due to improper loading, an unknown amount of NPS Sodium Persulfate (hazardous - UN1505) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the trailer floor at dock door #9. The caller has requested a contractor out for cleanup and containment and to bring drums for containment (Jeff Smith - Service Center Mgr approved). There is no regulatory reporting required for this release. ERTS will upload the BOL, SDS and create a waste container entry. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed less than a pound of the UN1505 Sodium Persulfate product released to a 1’ x 2’ area of the trailer floor and impacting the shrink wrap due to improper loading. The crew overpacked the fiber drums (2) 55-gallon poly drums and placed the PPE into a 30-gallon poly drum and submerged the PPE in water prior. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 1500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 03/08/2025, at 1313 hours, personnel at the CSX yard in Selkirk, New York, reported product leaking from inside the valve box of car IAPX 1084, a tank car residue: last contained, Argon, refrigerated liquid. The car was isolated and the customer, Airgas, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2025-03-08-00044). David Scoons, a CSX Senior Manager of Hazardous Materials, responded to the incident along with HEPACO a CSX emergency response contractor. It was determined the cause of the release was due to the liquid line valve being partially and the secondary securement not properly applied. Response personnel closed the valve properly secured the valve and secondary securement stopping the release. The shipper’s representative, George Ryan (518-526-3322), was notified of the condition found and the corrective actions taken.

  • Description: At 02:08 EST on 3/7, Tony Hobson with XPO-LJS contacted ERTS to report a spill of about 2 quarts of an unidentified material onto the trailer floor from a pallet of boxes. The pallet was poorly loaded and damaged in transit from XDM. The material cannot be identified as the pallet is wrapped in opaque shrink wrap, and ERTS advised the terminal not to handle the material as it is a regulated corrosive. ERTS will dispatch a contractor to assist. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of UN2491 Hood & Flue Cleaner Concentrate product released to a 2’x3’ area of the trailer floor and small amount to the concrete floor due to a forklift puncture. The crew found (2) boxes damaged, each containing (4) ½ gallon jugs each. The crew cleaned up the spill with citric acid. The cardboard, damaged poly jugs, waste product, oil-dri, citric acid and PPE were containerized into (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2025030221
item.description:
Report E-2025030221

Identified by scraper @ 2025-04-15T00:53:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-27
  • City: CINCINNATI
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: WORLD FUEL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2700
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 2/27/2025 at 04:15pm EST, a World Fuel Services, Inc. (WFS) Cincinnati Tank Wagon driver was making a delivery to a 4,000 gallon underground storage tank (UST) located at Springfield TWP Police Department in Cincinnati, OH. During the delivery, product started overfilling from the UST connection resulting in a uncontrol release of gasoline to the environment at 16:18 EST. The employee, after noticing the spill, ran to shut the pump off and then grabbed spill pads to mitigate the spill. The employee attempted to clean-up spill and then left the site without reporting to it to WFS Operations or HSE personnel. At 18:20 EST the Springfield TWP Police Department notified the WFS Sales Representative of the spill, and then they reported it to WFS Operations and HSE. HEPACO and WFS Operations were dispatched to the site to clean-up spill and investigate. Calculated release is 70 gallons of regular 87 unleaded gasoline. Spill impacted 15’ x 25’ area of the parking lot. Spill flowed to a storm drain which discharged into a tributary of West Fork Mill Creek. The local fire department was dispatched and used 500 gallons of water to flush the product out of the drain. Shortly after, the area received heavy precipitation. These two events resulted in the majority of product not being recovered. Oil dry was used to clean-up residual product in the parking lot. One 55-drum of impacted oil dry was recovered. Oil booms were placed at the storm drain and at the outfall. They were inspected after the next rain event on 3/5/2025. No signs of product were visible. Delivery order was double dispatched on 2/27/2025. Another employee delivered to the site that morning. An old reoccurring order was placed on the second truck/employee. And an incorrect drop fitting was used for the tank wagon delivery to a UST. This resulted in not a close system causing the overfill prevention device to not function properly. The employee did not follow procedures and was not at the point of flow during delivery. Th employee was distracted by being on their phone while sitting on a picnic table away from the truck and pump hose. Truck camera footage showed one minute, and ten seconds went by until employee noticed the release. The employee did not confirm ullage and did not stick the tank or obtain a tank level reading report prior to delivery which would have prevented the spill. WFS spoke with and notified Ohio EPA of the spill at 19:00 EST on 2/27/2025. Ohio EPA, HEPACO, and WFS Operations completed a site walkthrough on 2/28/2025. Ohio EPA approved oil booms placement and to inspect after next precipitation event. Ohio EPA were informed on 3/5/2025 of no additional signs of product and approved removal of oil booms. Ohio EPA issued a Notice of Response and Regulatory Interest (NRRI). On 2/27/5025, NRC was notified of the spill at 21:04 EST and Hamilton County EMA was notified of spill and at 19:15 EST

When he checked it at 50psi with Ferrous the tanker was overflowing. He quickly shut down the flow of material, let the site, dispatch and EHS know. He was unable to confirm amount as it went into the sites containment. Site confirmed 80-100 gallons the next day, which is an RQ and it was reported to the NRC. No exposure or injuries

  • Description: The undeclared hazardous materials were tendered by a third party and picked up by carrier and delivered to destination facility (wastewater treatment facility were described as non-regulated wastewater) and as such the incident constituted an undeclared material that was non-conforming to the approval issued by consignee. On inquiry with the shipper/wastewater generator, it was discovered that an unknown quantity of sodium hydroxide had been combined with the wastewater. The wastewater was placed into a tanker of aluminum construction, so the mechanism of failure appears straightforward. The release occurred on consignee property before being assessed for formal receipt and treatment. The release was controlled and the affected area is being remediated.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Please note on Saturday, 1/18/2025, CBP officers were at our facility to inspect a radioactive shipment arriving on LX040 01/18/2025. While they were inspecting the shipment, their radiation detector system flagged at an unusually high radiation level. They advised us to clear everyone and not let anyone come within 30 ft of it. They left us with that information and let us know to make decisions as we see appropriate. 724-76678490 (2 packages), CBP advised that this packaging was not appropriate, and they would not go any closer than 5 ft from where these 2 packages were located. CBP did not provide reading levels, only that the package was not appropriate, and they would not go any closer than 5 feet from where the 2 packages were located. Immediately action: All agents were moved to the export side of the facility until we figured out a way to handle this. The customer representative was here to retrieve it at the same time CBP was here. We ended up delivering the pieces to the representative and advised the Airline.
